Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Large: Collaborative Research: Enabling Privacy-Utility Trade-Offs in Pervasive Computing Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Pervasive computing, such as sensors in smartphones, buildings, automobiles and cities, result in increased sharing of sensor data, whether initiated by users or by other authorities such as service providers, government entities, interest groups, and individuals. Embedded in this data is information which others, even using sophisticated data mining algorithms, can fuse to construct a virtual biography of our activities, revealing private behaviors and lifestyle patterns. Researchers in this project are devising computational methods to let users exercise privacy control over their personal sensory data that is shared.

Intellectual Merit: The project is developing a user-configurable cryptographically-secure ?privacy shield? to run on smartphones and act upon sensor information flowing to other users, apps, and services. To make privacy understandable, the user is presented with a higher level abstraction for expressing privacy and sharing in terms of rich inferences and contexts drawn from sensor measurements. The user can designate some inferences and contexts as private. To provide privacy while ensuring the quality of service provided by the recipients of the sensory information, the system also incorporates algorithms which, over time, learn a personalized model of the privacy risk from sharing an inference. The theoretical concepts and the system realization are being validated via user studies in mobile health and personal sensing.

Broader Impacts: By providing better understanding of the behavioral privacy problem and risks inherent in sharing seemingly innocuous data, results from this project will lead to a more educated and informed citizenry, regulators, and policy makers, and provide effective tools for privacy management to those who share sensory information.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching vision of this seed project  was to explore principled theories and architectural principles for pervasive computing systems that preserve privacy while providing utility to data consumers, and investigate associated algorithmic foundations, run-time software services, static-analysis methods, and hardware mechanisms, with experimental validation. The research focused both specifically on mobile personal sensing applications as well as sensor instrumented physical spaces. 

 

Significant advances were made along each front. The grant provided seed funds to build what has now emerged as a large scale pervasive computing  testbed entitied TIPPERS that consists of

(a) an instrumted building with variety of sensor subsystems for localizing individuals inside the building, and for monitoring  the energy usage. These subsystems include beacons, WiFi Access points, cameras, energy meters, plug-load devices, smart phones as sensors, etc. 

(b) an experimental  IoT  system technology that embodies privacy by design principle. The system offers higher level semantic abstractions to express privacy policies, supports mechanisms to translate higher level policies to individual sensor control, provides mechanisms to intercept data flow between components to infuse new privacy technologies, and also maintains detaiiled logs to support evaluation of privacy achieved via different technologies.

The TIPPERS system , created in part through the NSF project is now funded in collaboration with Honeywell Labs by DARPA through a newly launched Brandeis Project. TIPPERS plays a role of a IoT cluster which includes collaborators working of diverse privacy technologies ranging from secure multi-party computation (Stealth Technologies), differential privacy (Duke, Colgate, Massachussets), and privacy metrics (Galois, Cybernetica) and privacy policies (CMU)  in addition to UCI team.

The grant also resulted in exploration of a new Xprotect middleware for android devices that sits between the mobile android apps and the sensors (GPS, accelerometer, etc) to empower users to control information leakage to different apps. In addition, mechanisms for users to send and receive context aware messages the delivery of which is based on context variables becoming true was developed. Also, the grant led to development of mobipedia - a (semi-automated) knowledge base about mobile apps.  The current version of Mobipedia focuses on Android apps and incorporates three important data sources: PlayDrone, PrivacyGrade, and the Android permissions website. Mobipedia contains information of more than one million Android apps including: application category, meta-data (author, reviews, rating, released), permissions requested (in Android), similar apps, etc. Mobipedia is intended as a community resource to benefit applications and research projects by accessing the knowledge base for information about mobile apps using a standard M representation format (RDF). Until now, developing such applications would require an effort to find and integrate the information which is split in different sources and published with different formats.

 

 

From a social media perspective, our study showed author linkability using stylometry in contributed social media content and  explored crowdsourcing as a way to rewrite contributed content to mitigate stylometric based linkability. In addition the work explored classiification of tweets as containing direct and indirect PII based on language level features using which mechanisms to create summaries that do not contain identifying features that can be used for linkability can be designed.
